DOCS

Our goal is to use terminal commands to send commands to a Parrot AR Drone 2.0 and successfuly make the connect. The end goal of this project is to fly a drone using a Leap Motion Controller and through the browser.

Core Features

  • Create a python-based API that will communicate with a front-end server
  • Send terminal commands to the drone, that the drone will then execute
  • Send commands via the front-end web application (i.e. this web app)
  • Send useful drone information to a front-end user interface
  • Create a module that anyone with a drone can pip install, then use to control their personal drone

API Endpoints

The API endpoints are served using bottle.py.

Drone Commands

All instructions sent to the drone are done through http post requests to http://127.0.0.1:3000/do/<command>.

/do/ Available Commands

  • takeoff
  • land
  • hover
  • move_left
  • move_right
  • move_down
  • move_up
  • move_forward
  • move_backward
  • turn_left
  • turn_right

A call to any of these commands would look like: curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:3000/do/takeoff

/do/ API Endpoint Behavior

If a command is successful, the server will return a 200 OK response with json containing all the related fields to the drone's current status. If a command isn't valid, the server will respond with a 404 NOT FOUND with a body containing: Bad Command: <command>

200 OK Response Json

200 OKs will respond with the following JSON template:

{
          "0": {
            "vy": Velocity along Y Axis,
            ...
            "battery": Percentage of battery,
            "altitude": Integer in mm,
            "ctrl_state": One of the following integers,
            # 0: Unknown, 1: Inited, 2: Landed, 4: Hovering, 6: Taking Off, 8: Landing
            "vx": Velocity along X Axis,
            "vz": Velocity along Z Axis,
          } ...
        }

There is more information that is sent back that can be found here

Drone navdata

At any time, a user can hit 127.0.0.1:3000/navdata to see the 200 OK JSON response from any of the valid /do/s. The format is still the same.

Client Example

This client was built using AngularJS and NodeJS.

Click here to install nodeJS.

After installing node:


    git clone http://github.com/DroneQuest/drone-client
    npm install
    node client-server.js

Then go to your broswer and enter 127.0.0.1:8080/#/fly. This runs fly cmmands after you install the bottle server, below.

Requirements

This software was tested with the following setup:

  • Python 2.6.6
  • Psyco 1.6 (recommended)
  • Pygame 1.8.1 (only for the demo)
  • Unmodified AR.Drone firmware 1.5.1

Stretch Goals

  • Get live video in the browser during flight
  • Use VR goggles that will connect to the drone cameras
